name: Krishi Bhagya Yojana
description: Program to improve water availability in rainfed areas through on-farm structures such as farm ponds, check dams, and field bunds.
target_group: Farmers in rainfed areas of Karnataka

other: Must be a farmer in rainfed area

benefits: Subsidy for construction of farm ponds
Support for shaded nets around ponds
Promotion of micro-irrigation systems

how_to_apply.deadline: Ongoing scheme with seasonal application windows

faq.q: What is the maximum subsidy available?
faq.a: Subsidy amounts vary based on farm size and type of structure being built.

faq.q: Can tenant farmers apply?
faq.a: Yes, with proper documentation of tenancy from landowner.

implementation: Launched in 2016-17 under state order 'ಕೃಇ 146 ಕೃಯೋಕಾ 2015'; managed by the Department of Agriculture

name: Raitha Siri Yojana
description: Scheme to provide financial assistance to farmers facing crop loss due to natural calamities or market price crashes.
target_group: Farmers affected by crop losses in Karnataka

other: Must be a farmer with documented crop loss

benefits: Direct cash support per hectare based on assessed loss
Additional support for millet growers under program expansion

how_to_apply.deadline: Applications open after official declaration of calamity or price crash

faq.q: How is crop loss assessed?
faq.a: Local agriculture officers conduct field visits to assess and document crop damage.

faq.q: What is the maximum compensation available?
faq.a: Compensation rates are determined based on crop type and extent of damage as per state guidelines.

implementation: Established under State-order Kṛ.ಇ.45/ಕೃಯೋಕಾ-2019; guidelines published for 2019–20 onward

name: Suvarna Bhoomi Yojana
description: Program to encourage small and marginal farmers (including SC/ST) to develop land and diversify into high-value crops.
target_group: Small and marginal farmers of Karnataka
benefits: Financial assistance of ₹10,000 per two acres
Support for land leveling and bunding
Assistance for diversification to cash/millet crops

steps: Apply through local agriculture department office
how_to_apply.deadline: Seasonal application windows as notified by department

faq.q: Can tenant farmers apply for this scheme?
faq.a: Yes, with proper documentation of tenancy rights.

faq.q: What crops are promoted under this scheme?
faq.a: High-value cash crops and millets are prioritized for diversification support.

implementation: Initially launched in 2011-12; revamped and continued with modifications

name: Krishi Yantra Dhare Yojana
description: Scheme to provide access to farm machinery via Custom Hiring Centres (CHCs) at the hobli level.
target_group: Farmers needing access to agricultural machinery

other: Trusts or farmer groups for establishing CHCs

benefits: Subsidized rental access to tractors, harvesters, and other machinery
Subsidy for establishment of Custom Hiring Centres by trusts or farmer groups

steps: For farmers: register at local CHC for equipment usage
how_to_apply.deadline: Annual application cycle as per RKVY guidelines

faq.q: How much subsidy is available for establishing a CHC?
faq.a: Subsidy rates vary as per RKVY guidelines, typically covering a substantial portion of machinery cost.

faq.q: What machinery is available at CHCs?
faq.a: Tractors, tillers, harvesters, threshers, planters, and other specialized equipment based on local farming needs.

implementation: Funded under RKVY since 2014-15

name: Organic Farming Mission (Savayava Siri)
description: Mission to promote cluster-based organic and millet farming to enhance soil health and farmer incomes.
target_group: Farmers interested in organic cultivation

other: Farmers willing to adopt organic practices
Preference for forming 10-20 hectare organic clusters

benefits: Input subsidies for organic farming
Training on organic cultivation methods
Certification support under NPOP
Marketing assistance for organic produce

how_to_apply.deadline: Rolling applications based on program cycles

faq.q: How long does organic certification take?
faq.a: Typically 2-3 years for full organic certification, with transitional certification available earlier.

faq.q: Is there marketing support for organic produce?
faq.a: Yes, the mission helps connect organic farmers with premium markets and provides branding support.

implementation: Based on Karnataka's 'Savayava Krishi Neethi' (2004) policy framework

name: Krishi Honda Scheme
description: Scheme offering subsidies for on-farm water harvesting structures (farm ponds) similar to Krishi Bhagya Yojana.
target_group: Farmers in water-scarce regions

other: Must be a farmer with suitable land for pond construction
Priority to areas with water scarcity

benefits: Subsidy for construction of farm ponds
Technical assistance for pond design and construction
Integration with micro-irrigation where applicable

how_to_apply.deadline: Seasonal application windows

faq.q: How is this different from Krishi Bhagya Yojana?
faq.a: Krishi Honda is often implemented alongside Krishi Bhagya under the same state order, with specific focus on farm pond construction.

faq.q: What is the minimum land requirement for pond construction?
faq.a: Varies based on pond size, but typically requires adequate space for effective water harvesting without affecting primary cultivation.

implementation: Often implemented alongside Krishi Bhagya Yojana under the same state order

name: Krishi Protsaha Dhana
description: Initiative to incentivize adoption of priority crops (e.g., millets) and best agricultural practices via direct payments.
target_group: Farmers cultivating priority crops
benefits: Direct financial incentives based on crop area and type
Additional support for adopting sustainable practices
Technical guidance on priority crop cultivation

steps: Register crop details on Raitha Mitra portal
how_to_apply.deadline: Announced annually in State Budget alongside Raitha Siri

faq.q: Which crops receive the highest incentives?
faq.a: Millets and other drought-resistant native crops typically receive priority incentives.

faq.q: Is there a minimum area requirement to qualify?
faq.a: Requirements vary by crop type and are announced in annual guidelines.

implementation: Announced annually in the State Budget alongside Raitha Siri

name: Pashu Bhagya Scheme
description: Program to develop livestock units (cattle, sheep, goats, pigs, poultry) among farmers for additional income generation.
target_group: Farmers interested in livestock rearing

other: Farmers with suitable space for livestock rearing
Priority to small and marginal farmers

benefits: Capital subsidy (30-50% of unit cost)
Insurance premium subsidy on a limited number of animals
Training on scientific animal husbandry practices

steps: Apply through local veterinary office or online portal
Purchase of animals and establishment of unit
how_to_apply.deadline: Continuous scheme with periodic application windows

required_documents: Land Records/Proof of space for livestock

faq.q: What types of livestock units are supported?
faq.a: The scheme supports cattle, sheep, goats, pigs, and poultry units based on farmer preference and local suitability.

faq.q: Is training provided before starting a livestock unit?
faq.a: Yes, beneficiaries receive mandatory training in scientific animal husbandry practices.

implementation: Administered by Department of Animal Husbandry & Veterinary Services

name: Krishi Niravari Nigama Scheme
description: Program to support irrigation infrastructure via Karnataka Neeravari Nigam Limited (KNNL).
target_group: Farmers in command areas of irrigation projects

other: Community groups for lift irrigation projects

benefits: Canal repairs and maintenance
Development of lift irrigation systems
Maintenance of distribution networks in command areas
Improved water availability for agriculture

steps: Apply through KNNL offices or local irrigation department
Community applications for lift irrigation projects
how_to_apply.deadline: Project-based applications as per KNNL schedule

faq.q: How are command areas determined?
faq.a: Command areas are technically mapped regions that can receive water from specific irrigation projects.

faq.q: Can individual farmers apply for canal repairs?
faq.a: Generally, canal repairs are prioritized based on technical assessments and benefit to larger areas, but farmers can report issues requiring attention.

implementation: Managed by Karnataka Neeravari Nigam Limited (KNNL)

name: Karnataka Solar Agricultural Pump Scheme (Surya Raitha)
description: Initiative to replace diesel pumps with solar-powered irrigation systems to reduce costs and environmental impact.
target_group: Farmers using diesel pumps for irrigation

other: Farmers with existing diesel pumps or new irrigation needs
Adequate sunlight exposure at pump location

benefits: Up to 60% subsidy on solar pump cost (central + state share)
Reduced operational costs through renewable energy
Environmental benefits through reduced emissions

steps: Apply through KREDL or local electricity office
how_to_apply.deadline: Annual application cycles as per MNRE guidelines

faq.q: What is the capacity range of solar pumps available?
faq.a: The scheme typically supports 3HP to 10HP solar pumps based on irrigation requirements.

faq.q: Is maintenance support provided after installation?
faq.a: Yes, vendors are required to provide maintenance support for 5 years after installation.

implementation: KREDL in partnership with MNRE; projects since 2014-15

name: Karnataka Agro-Processing Units Scheme
description: Program to develop food processing and storage infrastructure to reduce post-harvest losses and increase farmer incomes.
target_group: Farmers, Entrepreneurs, FPOs interested in food processing

other: Individuals, FPOs, cooperatives, or private companies
Technical and financial capability to establish processing units

benefits: Capital grant (25-35% of project cost) under MoFPI's Centrally-Sponsored Scheme
Technical assistance for project development
Market linkage support for processed products

how_to_apply.deadline: Quarterly application cycles as per MoFPI guidelines

faq.q: What types of processing units are eligible?
faq.a: Primary processing, secondary processing, storage facilities, cold chains, and packaging units for agricultural produce.

faq.q: Is there a minimum investment requirement?
faq.a: Yes, project size requirements vary by type of processing unit as per MoFPI guidelines.

implementation: Managed by Food Karnataka Limited under MoFPI's Centrally-Sponsored Scheme

name: Karnataka Bee Keeping Mission
description: Initiative to scale up scientific apiculture and honey production in the state.
target_group: Farmers and rural entrepreneurs interested in beekeeping
benefits: Subsidy for bee colonies and modern hives
Equipment support for honey extraction and processing
Training on scientific beekeeping methods
Marketing support for honey and bee products

steps: Apply through local agriculture department or NBHM portal
how_to_apply.deadline: Annual application cycles under NBHM guidelines

faq.q: How many bee boxes are provided under the scheme?
faq.a: Typically 5-10 bee boxes with colonies are provided to beginner beekeepers, with scope for expansion.

faq.q: Is training mandatory before receiving assistance?
faq.a: Yes, beneficiaries must complete a basic beekeeping training program before receiving colonies and equipment.

implementation: Operates under National Bee Board/NBHM guidelines

name: Karnataka Fisheries Development Scheme
description: Program to promote inland and marine fisheries via infrastructure, hatcheries, and training.
target_group: Fisherfolk and farmers interested in aquaculture

other: Traditional fisherfolk or farmers with suitable water bodies
Cooperatives and self-help groups involved in fisheries

benefits: Assistance for pond development and renovation
Support for establishing fish seed hatcheries
Extension services and training
Subsidy for cold storage and marketing infrastructure

steps: Technical evaluation of site and proposal
how_to_apply.deadline: Seasonal application cycles as per fisheries calendar

faq.q: What species of fish are recommended for cultivation?
faq.a: Freshwater species like Rohu, Catla, and Common Carp are recommended for inland aquaculture in Karnataka.

faq.q: Is there assistance for fishing equipment?
faq.a: Yes, the scheme provides subsidies for nets, boats, and other essential fishing equipment for eligible beneficiaries.

implementation: Administered by Department of Fisheries, Karnataka under National Fisheries Development Board guidelines

name: Krushi Aranya Protsaha Yojane (KAPY)
description: A scheme that promotes tree cover on private farmland by subsidizing seedlings and providing financial incentives for maintaining them over a three-year period.
target_group: All farmers with agricultural land in Karnataka

other: Excludes planting of Eucalyptus, Acacia, Casuarina, citrus, grafted mango, rubber, etc.

benefits: Subsidized seedlings at ₹1-5 each, depending on poly-bag size
Incentive of ₹35 per surviving seedling at end of Year 1
Incentive of ₹40 per surviving seedling at end of Year 2
Incentive of ₹50 per surviving seedling at end of Year 3
Total incentive of ₹125 per surviving seedling over three years
Long-term returns in fruit, fodder, timber, etc.

steps: Register by end of May at nearest Range Forest Office (₹10 fee)
Obtain seedlings at subsidized rates from departmental nurseries
Participate in maintenance checks for incentive disbursement over three years
how_to_apply.deadline: End of May each year

faq.q: Which tree species are promoted under this scheme?
faq.a: Native and fruit-bearing species suitable for agro-forestry, excluding Eucalyptus, Acacia, Casuarina, citrus, grafted mango, and rubber.

faq.q: How is the survival of seedlings verified?
faq.a: Forest department officials conduct periodic field visits to verify seedling survival before releasing incentive payments.

implementation: Implemented by Karnataka Forest Department; incentives disbursed directly to farmer bank accounts after verification of seedling survival

name: Ganga Kalyana Scheme
description: Program providing 100% subsidized borewells, pump sets and electrification to small/marginal and minority farmers to enhance irrigation coverage through groundwater exploitation.
target_group: Small/marginal farmers and minority community farmers
benefits: 100% subsidy for borewell drilling
100% subsidy for pump set installation
100% subsidy for electrification of pump set
Grant of ₹3.75 Lakh per individual borewell in Bangalore Rural, Kolar, Chikkaballapur, Ramanagara, Tumkur districts
Grant of ₹2.25 Lakh per individual borewell in other districts

steps: Complete online form via Jan Samarth portal
Submit printed form with required documentation
Implementation of borewell and irrigation infrastructure
how_to_apply.deadline: Applications accepted year-round

required_documents: RTC (Record of Rights, Tenancy and Crops)

faq.q: Is there any beneficiary contribution required?
faq.a: No, the scheme provides 100% subsidy for eligible farmers.

faq.q: What happens if water is not found after drilling?
faq.a: The department bears the risk; farmers are not liable for unsuccessful borewells.

implementation: Implemented by Karnataka Minorities Development Corporation (KMDC) in coordination with state Energy Department

name: Bhoochetana Scheme
description: Program aimed at enhancing rainfed crop productivity through soil health management, micronutrient application, fertilizer demonstrations and best-practice trainings.
target_group: Farmers in rainfed agricultural regions of Karnataka
benefits: Soil testing services
Soil health cards
Nutrient management guidance
Quality seed provision
Technical support from district facilitators
Yield improvement up to 30% in pilot districts

how_to_apply.deadline: Program operated from 2009-2019 (now closed)

faq.q: How many farmers benefited from this scheme?
faq.a: Approximately 4 million farmers across Karnataka benefited from the program during its operational period.

faq.q: What were the main achievements of the scheme?
faq.a: The scheme demonstrated significant yield gains in rainfed regions, with increases up to 30% in pilot districts. Its approaches were later integrated into mainstream agricultural extension services.

implementation: Started in 2009 by CM B.S. Yediyurappa under RKVY (Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojana); implemented by Department of Agriculture, Government of Karnataka; closed in 2019

name: Chief Minister's Raitha Vidya Nidhi Scheme
description: Scholarship program to encourage higher education among children of farmers by providing financial assistance across school to postgraduate levels.
target_group: Children of farmers in Karnataka

other: Must be a child of a farmer

benefits: ₹2,000-3,000 for PUC/ITI/Diploma courses
₹5,000-5,500 for non-professional undergraduate courses
₹7,500-8,000 for professional undergraduate courses (e.g., LLB, nursing)
₹10,000-11,000 for professional undergraduate/postgraduate courses (e.g., MBBS, BTech)
₹2,000 per year for girls (Classes VIII-X)

steps: Benefits disbursed via Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) to beneficiary's account
how_to_apply.deadline: Varies annually, typically after academic year begins

faq.q: Can children of landless agricultural laborers apply?
faq.a: No, the scheme is specifically for children of farmers who own agricultural land.

faq.q: Is there any minimum academic performance requirement?
faq.a: Yes, applicants must have passed the previous academic year/examination.

implementation: Implemented by Karnataka Department of Agriculture in coordination with Social Welfare Department; scholarships disbursed directly to student bank accounts

name: Karnataka State Farm Mechanization Scheme
description: Program to promote use of modern agricultural machinery to boost productivity, reduce labor dependency and modernize farming operations through substantial subsidies.
target_group: Individual farmers, joint farming groups, and registered cooperatives in Karnataka

other: Must own/operate minimum 1 acre of land

benefits: 50% subsidy on machinery cost (up to ₹1 Lakh for common farmers)
Up to ₹5 Lakh subsidy for selected equipment
90% subsidy for SC/ST farmers
Equipment includes tractors, tillers, seeders, sprayers, power threshers, etc.

how_to_apply.deadline: Applications accepted throughout the year based on fund availability

faq.q: Can farmers apply for multiple types of machinery?
faq.a: Yes, but there are annual limits on total subsidy amount per farmer.

faq.q: Is there any verification process after purchasing the equipment?
faq.a: Yes, agricultural officers verify the machinery purchase before subsidy is released.

implementation: Implemented by Department of Agriculture, Government of Karnataka under KKISAN portal; subsidy released directly to manufacturer/dealer to ensure quality

name: Karnataka Biofuel Policy Initiatives (2025-26)
description: Comprehensive policy framework to enhance energy security and environmental sustainability by promoting production and use of biodiesel and ethanol from sustainable feedstocks.
target_group: Farmers, entrepreneurs, research institutions, and biofuel producers in Karnataka

other: Research institutions working on biofuel technologies

benefits: Tax exemptions for biofuel production
Duty rebates on equipment purchase
Capital grants for biofuel plants
Support for biogas and bio-CNG production
Incentives for biodiesel from non-edible oilseeds
Support for ethanol from sugarcane juice and damaged grains
R&D collaboration with German universities (Dortmund University of Applied Sciences)

how_to_apply.mode: Through Karnataka State Bio-Energy Development Board
steps: Submit project proposal to Bio-Energy Development Board
how_to_apply.deadline: Ongoing program for 2025-26 fiscal year

contact.helpline: Karnataka State Bio-Energy Development Board Helpline

faq.q: What types of biofuel production are supported?
faq.a: The policy supports biodiesel from non-edible oilseeds, ethanol from sugarcane juice and damaged grains, biogas, and bio-CNG production.

faq.q: Are there specific R&D collaborations?
faq.a: Yes, the state has MoUs with German universities, particularly Dortmund University of Applied Sciences, for R&D and technology transfer in biofuel production.

implementation: Implemented by Karnataka State Bio-Energy Development Board under Department of Energy; funded through state budget allocation for 2025-26, public-private partnerships, and international grants

name: Horticultural Producers' Cooperative Marketing and Processing Society (HOPCOMS)
description: Cooperative marketing society that eliminates intermediaries by directly marketing horticultural produce, ensuring fair prices for farmers and quality goods for consumers.
target_group: Horticultural farmers in Karnataka

other: Must join as member of HOPCOMS cooperative

benefits: Direct market access eliminating middlemen
Fair price realization for produce
Collection, grading, and processing facilities
Distribution to hospitals, factories, hostels
Access to processing units (juice production)
Participation in fruit/vegetable festivals

steps: Apply for membership at nearest HOPCOMS office
Start supplying produce to collection centers
how_to_apply.deadline: Membership open throughout the year

faq.q: Which districts are covered by HOPCOMS operations?
faq.a: HOPCOMS covers Bangalore Urban/Rural, Kolar, Ramanagar, Mandya, Mysuru, and Chikkaballapura districts.

faq.q: What is the daily throughput of HOPCOMS operations?
faq.a: HOPCOMS handles approximately 100 tonnes of horticultural produce daily.

implementation: Operates under Department of Horticulture, Government of Karnataka; headquartered at Lalbagh, Bengaluru; governed by Board of Directors with majority farmer representation; approximately 12,680 farmer members with paid-up capital of ₹26.59 million (as of 2014)

name: Relief for Farmer Suicides
description: Emergency financial assistance program to provide immediate relief to families of farmers who die by suicide, aimed at mitigating economic distress and supporting surviving family members.
target_group: Families of farmers who have died by suicide due to agricultural indebtedness

other: Death ruled as suicide by Forensic Science Laboratory (FSL) report

benefits: Ex gratia payment of ₹5 Lakh to family of deceased
Monthly pension of ₹2,000 to surviving spouse
Benefits disbursed upon verification of suicide linked to indebtedness

steps: Next-of-kin apply through District Agriculture Office
Approval and disbursement via Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT)
how_to_apply.deadline: Application should be filed within one year of the incident

faq.q: How is the link between suicide and agricultural indebtedness established?
faq.a: A district-level committee reviews each case using police reports, FSL findings, loan documents, and other evidence to establish the connection.

faq.q: How long does the approval process take?
faq.a: The verification and approval process typically takes 2-3 months after submission of complete documentation.

implementation: Jointly implemented by Department of Agriculture and Department of Rural Development; relief amounts disbursed directly to beneficiary bank accounts after case verification by district committee
